awd_titl_txt: Implementation Grant: Pi-STEM E3 (Pathways into STEM Careers, Enrichment, Engagement, and Empowerment)
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at Lawson State Community College seeks to build on previous successful efforts to increase participation of African-American students in STEM disciplines.  The goal of this project is to significantly improve student success rates in the community college's STEM programs by creating critical thinkers, increasing STEM literacy, and educating the next generation of STEM professionals. A significant broader impact is the  collaboration between the community college and its middle school and high school partners.

The overarching goal of the project is to increase the number of underrepresented minorities and women in STEM career paths by focusing on creating a year-round STEM Enrichment Institute and academic enhancement program for eighth graders and high school students; implementing a college bridge program for incoming freshman and graduating high school seniors; and providing research, mentoring, and academic development opportunities for STEM students, improving persistence and efficacy. The project will employ activities and strategies that are evidence-based, but will be studied for effectiveness in the setting of this two-year institution.  The project will be advised and evaluated for effectiveness by internal and external advisory boards and by a team of evaluators. This project provides a model for how community colleges can take a more direct, purposeful role in impacting the potential employment pool of STEM professionals.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on (1) building on previous successful efforts to increase participation of African-American students in STEM disciplines and (2) significantly improving student success rates in Lawson State Community College's STEM programs by creating critical thinkers, increasing STEM literacy, and educating the next generation of STEM professionals.  Award #1719329 titled, Implementation Grant: Pi-STEM E3 (Pathways into STEM Careers, Enrichment, Engagement, and Empowerment), contributed to the STEM pipeline by hosting an annual STEM Enrichment Institute (SEI) for middle and high school students and a Bridge Program for incoming freshman and graduating high school seniors.  This component incorporated dual enrollment and provided in-depth STEM exposure and experiences for pre-college students historically underrepresented in STEM. Over the period of the grant, SEI and Bridge participants earned over 100 total credit hours in a math and/or science course at Lawson State. Additionally, at the onset of the pandemic, the Project Director promptly organized a novel virtual REU with UAB’s MERIT program that allowed 13 undergraduates to participate in research projects with postdoctoral fellows for Summer 2020 (when all other REUs accepted by STEM scholars were canceled).  Lawson State is the first community college to receive an HBCU-UP grant, and the knowledge gained over three implementations will strengthen future projects.

Award #1719329 significantly impacted the development of 285 8th graders and high school students who participated in a STEM Enrichment Institute and a STEM Bridge Program as well as 100 students enrolled in a STEM Scholars Program. Additionally, 84 students completed REUs, and 115 STEM majors transitioned to a four-year university. STEM scholars secured co-authorship on peer-reviewed publications, 21 presented at local, regional, and national conferences (with a total of 49 presentations), and at least 28 earned bachelor’s degrees in STEM according to the National Student Clearinghouse. Additionally, STEM scholars at Lawson State have garnered a reputation for winning awards for their research presentations at national conferences each year while competing with juniors and seniors from highly ranked four-year institutions (13 awards since 2017).  Under  Award #1719329, the STEMPOSIUM magazine was launched as well as Lawson State’s chapter of the National Society of Black Engineers in 2021. Before the pandemic, the number of STEM graduates increased from 2017 to 2020 by 19%. Guest speakers and STEM role models from employers such as NASA, Boeing, Lockheed Martin, and Southern Company facilitated talks and workshops with STEM majors at the College. Educational partnerships were established with the UAB MERIT Program and Samford University’s STEM Scholars Program.  The Center of Excellence in STEM was established and institutionalized on campus in 2017 which is the only center of its kind in the state.  This Center, supported through the leveraging of state, federal, corporate, and community resources, will continue to implement and disseminate innovative STEM instructional strategies, best practices, and research. 

This project was successful in letting targeted groups know about the STEM programs at Lawson State Community College and potential STEM career paths.  In addition, this project was successful in increasing STEM majors’ propensity for successful transfer to four-year institutions.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2024
Modified by: Shawanda Thomas
